caption.p: Research themes and core concepts identified within key research focussing on ‘ Cognition’ presented for each focus level (whether the articles examined the managerial, organisational or general societal populations)

td.p: Various factors shape managerial cognition (individual; organisational; societal). E.g. Individual ability variables and motivation variables; Individual moral maturity and perceived moral intensity of sustainability issue; temporality; mindfulness training on cognitive abilities; Association between individual ethics, honesty and moral development; decision-making horizon influence on sustainability frame
Determining- Factors determine cognition towards sustainability
Dual process- Implicit and explicit; Effortful (conscious thought) and effortless (automatic processing) aspects
Evolving- Evolution of cognition over time
Co-evolution - Increased complexity of knowledge (non-financial) increases proactive sustainability initiatives
Malleable- Cognition can be actively shaped e.g. through mindfulness training
Eberhardt-Toth & Wasieleski ( 2013)
Gröschl et al. ( 2019)
Siqueira & Pitassi ( 2016)
Chung & Hsu ( 2017)
Sharma & Jaiswal ( 2018)

Balance between individual cognitions and external factors. E.g. between individual cognitions and external resource support (eco-innovation); balance between individual cognition on climate change (local and global) and local capabilities; response to stakeholder pressure
Thresholds to action- Support factors internal and external to organisation
Tensions- Competing knowledge and views in creating a climate change strategy
Shaping- Response shaped by cognition e.g. Stakeholder pressure
Peng & Liu ( 2016)
Lei et al. ( 2017)
Schaltenbrand et al. ( 2018)

Factors associated with cognition shape action. E.g. managerial moral reflectiveness shapes ethical leadership actions; Increased cognitive complexity shapes sustainability decisions; culture effects agency; knowledge of environmental strategy
Complexity- Increased cognitive complexity measured by lens differentiation (number of cognitive lenses used) and lens integration (connections between lenses) influencing sustainability decisions
Reflectivity- Managers considering morality in their experiences shape actions
Autonomy- Moderating factor between moral reflectiveness and ethical leadership
Determining- Effect of culture on moral agency
Gröschl et al. ( 2019)
Babalola et al. ( 2019)
Hiekkataipale & Lamsa ( 2019)
Yang et al. ( 2019)
An individual’s cognition shapes the frame they take in managing tensions. Both cognitions and frames are dynamic
Tensions- Understanding tensions by managers determines frame
Evolving- Frames evolve and change over time influencing and being influenced by the frames of others (Dynamic)
Shaping - Cognition shapes frame
Cognitive frames shape decisions made within companies by managers. Role of framing in managing tensions i.e. business case vs paradoxical frame
Tensions- Managing tensions between sustainability drivers
Influencing- Frames influence sensemaking
Determining- Frames determine decisions
Paradoxical- Including detailed search, multiple factors with a range of rationales in decision-making; Acceptance of tensions
Interacting- Frames interact within an organisation
Hahn et al. ( 2014)
Sharma & Jaiswal ( 2018)
Frames enable interpretation shaping action towards sustainability
General framing within an organisation shapes action. E.g. on future oriented behaviour; temporality impact of frame on environmental product/process innovation
Facilitator - Framing through language shapes action
Director- Temporality of frame impacts investment. E.g. framing over long term leads to innovation investment
Liang et al. (2019)
Liao ( 2016)

Issues arising from contrasting frames preventing action (in contrast to aligned frames). Contrasting frames may inhibit action around organisational goals requiring decoupling process. E.g. business and NGO collaboration. A common shared vision is necessary
Competing frames- Inhibiting action from competing frames within a diverse group. Shared cognition/Divergent cognitive representations
Collective framing- Process by which individual managerial frames come to be adopted across organisation

Frame decoupling- Decoupling of a frame is required before an alternative is adopted. Process involves separating each component and associated issue. Once decoupled components can be altered and combined to distinct organisational frames aligned with organisational goals
Engaging Paradox- Managing competing frames is necessary when two companies with different goals join e.g. business and NGO
Zuzul ( 2019)
Meyer et al. ( 2016)
Sharma & Bansal 2017)
Olazabal & Pascua ( 2015)
Focus of firm level frame shapes capabilities. E.g. capabilities in stakeholder integration, market sensing, and learning

tr.td: Director - Fame orientation directs capability development

td.p: The dominant frame in industry on developments e.g. renewable energy, technology deployment etc. progresses over the industry development

tr.td: Shared beliefs – Industry level shared beliefs shape managerial cognition

td.p: Cognition shapes perception and ability to learn from events. Learning from rare events is challenging but can be promoted. Learning in organisations usually occurs through systemization and programming. Adaptive capacity implications
Impediments- Uniqueness can impede leaning
Interconnected processes- Behavioural and cognitive learning simultaneously
Adaptive capacity- ability to learn from extreme events to promote resilience
Linguistic framing of firm documents can shape cognition of stakeholders in a misleading fashion. Legitimising through words and images

tr.td: Shaping - Framing to through language can deceive not directly but through linguistic constructions. Framing through image word combinations to elicit emotions and attention

Lefsrud et al., ( 2019)
Various factors shape an individual’s cognition. Cognitive bias. Cognition is also shaped by perceived social value
Interactions- Moral emotions interact with persuasion social influence
Dual process- Implicit and explicit; Effortful (conscious thought) and effortless (automatic processing) aspects. Conscious (cognitive) can shape unconscious(affective) response
Enhancing- Emotion and intuition
Causal relationship- Beliefs tied through integrated system
Shaping- Factors shape cognition include personal, outcome perception and social judgement
